proposals.reasoning: Most of the table has already converged on Alice + Diana as a reasonable baseline: both tend to be clear about their reasoning afterward, which gives us good info regardless of result. Starting with them fits the group’s preference for a straightforward first mission while keeping me and others off so we can evaluate their post-mission logic and avoid auto-clearing anyone from a single pass.

votes.comment: I know I’m good, and Diana is a reasonable, consensus early partner; Mission 1 is mainly for info, so no strong reason to avoid this pairing.
Both are unknown but neither is in my current worry pool; solid informational start without including multiple untested wildcards.
Table consensus is already on Alice+Diana as a clean info-gathering start, and staying aligned with that early keeps me from standing out while we see how they talk post-mission.
Standard info-rich start, I’m on it, and table consensus is aligned with using post-mission reasoning for reads.
I already said Alice + Diana is a fine baseline; rejecting now would be inconsistent and the info from their post-mission logic is still useful.

discussion.content: I obviously want to be on the first team, and I’d lean toward pairing with someone who’s willing to be transparent about their future team logic—Bob or Diana feel like reasonable early picks based on how they usually play.

I’m fine either being on or off the first mission, but if we’re keeping it simple I’d slightly prefer an Alice + Diana pair to start, since both tend to play pretty straightforwardly early. We can use how they talk about future teams as a baseline for reads.

Alice + Diana is a pretty safe-seeming start to me, since they’re both usually clear about their reasoning afterward. I’m fine staying off first mission and using their post-mission takes to start sorting trusts.

I’m okay with Alice + me as a starting pair, but I’d like us to commit now that whoever’s off this mission (especially Bob/Charlie/Eve) uses the result to pressure-test our logic rather than just auto-trusting an early pass.

Alice + Diana is fine as a baseline, but I’d really want us to treat a pass there as “one or both might be good” rather than instantly town-clearing the pair, so we still feel free to rotate in Bob/Charlie later if the patterns get weird.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1 with Alice and Diana was clean, giving us the only concrete positive signal so far. Keeping that proven core and adding Bob is the lowest-risk, highest-information choice: if this mission also succeeds, we have a very strong trusted trio; if it fails, we immediately narrow suspicion primarily to Bob (since double-evil on Mission 1 is impossible). Rotating in Charlie or Eve instead would add unnecessary variance when we already have a working baseline to build from.

votes.comment: Keeps the proven Alice/Diana core and adds just one new variable in Bob, giving strong info either way without unnecessary risk.
Keeps the only clean core together and adds just one new player, giving good info with minimal risk.
I don’t like auto-locking the same core plus Bob after just one mission; I’d prefer testing a different mix (including me or Eve) to avoid tunneling too early.

Mission 1’s Alice/Diana pair is our only clean info; adding Bob is a low-risk way to test one new player while preserving that core. A fail here strongly implicates Bob, a success gives us a powerful trusted trio.
Team follows the clean Mission 1 core and the table consensus is strongly in favor; rejecting now would be higher-variance and draw unnecessary suspicion.

discussion.content: Given Mission 1 was clean with me and Diana on it, I’m inclined to keep us as a core and add just one new person rather than changing too much at once. I’d be happy with a team like me, Diana, and Bob this round.

Sticking with the proven Alice/Diana core and adding me seems like the lowest-variance option right now, since blowing up a clean-looking team this early usually helps evil more than us. I’m good with that lineup unless someone has a strong reason to swap in Charlie or Eve instead.

I’m fine with Alice/Diana as a starting point, but auto-locking them after one clean mission feels a bit rushed. I’d actually prefer rotating in either Eve or me this round so we’re not tunneling on a single narrative too early.

I like keeping the Alice/Diana core for now and adding Bob as a low-drama way to get more info without throwing out our only clean data point. If this passes clean too, we’ll have a really strong base to reason from next round.

I’m okay with sticking to the Alice/Diana core for now, but I’d slightly prefer testing one of Charlie or me in the third slot instead of auto-sliding Bob in so we’re not basing everything on just one clean result. If we never rotate, we risk feeling good about a setup that could still be hiding a spy.

proposals.reasoning: Both previous missions succeeded with zero FAILs and had Alice and Diana as the common core. With the score already 2–0 in favor of good, the lowest-risk option is to stick with the only pair that has been empirically clean so far, rather than introducing new uncertainty by swapping in someone from the untested pool.

votes.comment: Two clean missions with this exact core makes it the lowest-variance choice; introducing new players now only increases risk without new upside at 2–0.
Both prior missions with this core were clean, and at 2–0 the lowest-variance play is to stick with the proven pair rather than introduce new risk.
If both are good, this almost certainly gives good their third clean win; better to force a team that includes at least one of the untested players.
Two clean missions with this same core and we’re already up 2–0; best to keep the proven pair and accept the small sleeper-evil risk.

At 2–0, locking in the same untested core without giving anyone else a chance to be vetted feels too autopilot; if evil is quietly passing, it’s most likely in the “proven” pair, so I’d rather force a broader test than hand over a potential clean win.

discussion.content: Given two clean missions with the common core of me and Diana, I’m most comfortable repeating that pair here; if anyone has a strong reason to swap one of us for Bob, I’d like to hear it before we change what’s working.

Given both missions with Alice and Diana on them have been clean, I’m inclined to keep that core together for a 2-person team here. I don’t see a compelling reason to break what’s working unless someone has a very strong mechanical argument.

I’m fine with sticking to the Alice+Diana core for now, but if an evil has been quietly passing so far it’s most likely hiding in that pair, so I’d like to hear each of you walk through your trust logic before we lock it in.

Given we’re up 2–0 with the common thread of Alice + me, I think we should stick with that core for this 2-person team, but I agree it’s worth keeping in the back of our minds that if evil has been quiet so far, it could still be hiding in a “proven” pair.

I don’t really see a strong reason to break up the Alice + Diana core here; if there’s a sleeper evil, I’d honestly expect it more in the wider pool of Bob/Charlie/me than in the pair that’s already carried two clean missions.

evil_discussion.content: I’m leaning Bob as Merlin: he keeps softly steering toward the Alice+Diana core while framing it as “lowest-variance” and “no strong reason to change,” which is exactly how a Merlin who *knows* the pair is safe would justify locking them without over-claiming logic. Alice and Diana both feel more like confident goods riding the confirmation of clean results, whereas Bob is consistently nudging in the right direction with just enough caution and deference to table consensus to avoid looking like he has extra info.

I’m mostly with Charlie on Bob as Merlin: his “lowest-variance” / “no strong reason” framing keeps subtly shepherding us back to the Alice+Diana core while sounding like he’s just risk-averse, which is exactly how I’d expect Merlin to justify consistently correct takes without overexplaining. Alice and Diana both read more like straightforward goods leaning into the clean results they’re on; Bob is the one repeatedly endorsing the right teams while carefully avoiding any hard pushes or detailed reasoning that would expose extra info.

assassin_phase.reasoning: Bob consistently nudges the table toward the correct Alice+Diana core while framing it as 'lowest-variance' and avoiding any strong, detailed mechanical arguments that might reveal extra information. Alice and Diana sound like straightforward goods trusting clean results they were on, whereas Bob’s careful, risk-averse justification pattern fits a Merlin who knows those teams are safe but is trying not to appear too certain.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well on early missions, helping secure three clean successes and building a trustworthy dynamic with Diana without overcomplicating team choices. However, I could have been more cautious about how clearly Bob appeared to be Merlin and tried harder to create doubt or alternate narratives for the assassin in the final discussions.

player_observations.Bob: Played a very clean, controlled Merlin game—missions were perfectly composed, but the consistency and accuracy of his reads likely made him stand out to the assassin at the end.
player_observations.Charlie: Showed good assassin discipline, staying patient through three straight successes and then capitalizing on subtle information and team patterns to correctly identify Merlin.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as reliably good, accepting and supporting the successful team setups without creating extra chaos, which helped reinforce trust in the good teams early on.
player_observations.Eve: Blended into the early game well despite leading a successful mission, avoiding obvious suspicion and contributing to an environment where evil could still win through the assassination rather than mission failures.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed completely on the good side for team selection and mission outcomes, which helped ensure all missions succeeded, but I was far too transparent about who I trusted and excluded, making it easier for the Assassin to identify me as Merlin. Next time I need to add more plausible doubt around my reads and be willing to make slightly suboptimal or ‘noisy’ choices so I’m not so clearly differentiated from regular good players.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very clean, consistently trustworthy good game, which made it easy to keep putting her on teams; her straightforward style also gave evil very little leverage to frame her as suspicious.
player_observations.Charlie: As Assassin, read the trust patterns very well and correctly locked onto me as Merlin despite the missions all succeeding, suggesting strong attention to subtle behavior rather than just mission results.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as quietly reliable and low-drama, which made her a natural repeat pick for teams and helped good maintain a cohesive, low-suspicion core.
player_observations.Eve: Managed to avoid enough suspicion despite being evil that the game reached an all-success state going into the assassination, indicating careful, low-profile play rather than overt disruption.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed quiet enough as Assassin to avoid drawing suspicion while carefully tracking who seemed to have extra information, which paid off with the correct Merlin guess on Bob despite all missions passing. I could improve by influencing team selections more aggressively earlier, as relying solely on the assassination left the outcome a bit too close and gave the good team a very clean mission record.

player_observations.Alice: Played in a straightforward, trustworthy manner and was repeatedly included on teams, suggesting a consistent, low-drama style that made her feel like a safe pick to others.
player_observations.Bob: Subtly steered successful teams and avoided overt accusations, which looked like someone with more information than a normal good player and ultimately tipped me off that he was Merlin.
player_observations.Diana: Seemed comfortable being on early teams and blending in, contributing to a very unified good side without strong polarization or loud reads.
player_observations.Eve: Provided solid cover for the evil team by allowing missions to succeed and not over-pushing suspicion, helping maintain a game state where the assassination became the decisive weapon.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-team and helped secure three clean mission successes, which supported trust-building among the good players. However, I didn’t push hard enough on endgame reads or assassination-risk discussion, and I could improve by more actively protecting potential Merlin candidates and questioning patterns that seemed too clean.

player_observations.Alice: Played very solidly pro-good, building trust through leading and joining only successful teams, which made her appear reliably loyal without drawing too much suspicion as Merlin.
player_observations.Bob: Balanced giving helpful direction with staying just subtle enough that the assassin could still narrow him down, suggesting he was somewhat readable as Merlin despite overall strong mission choices.
player_observations.Charlie: Showed good assassin instincts by correctly identifying Merlin, implying close attention to subtle voting patterns, team compositions, and small informational leaks from others’ behavior.
player_observations.Eve: Managed to blend in despite being evil on the very first successful mission, leveraging the string of clean missions to avoid suspicion and let the assassin win the game rather than trying to sabotage directly.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed low-key and non-threatening, letting the clean missions build a sense of safety while not drawing attention to myself as evil. I could improve by more actively steering team compositions instead of mostly riding along with the consensus, which would give me more control if the assassin had needed extra info or if suspicion patterns shifted unexpectedly.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to trust early clean results and stayed consistent with that trust, which made her predictable but also a stabilizing force in team selection. She didn’t push hard for alternative narratives, which helped evil hide but could hurt her if evil ever manipulated early mission outcomes.
player_observations.Bob: Played a very subtle Merlin, giving just enough guidance through supportive voting and team acceptance rather than loud accusations. That low-profile approach worked well until the assassin picked up on the pattern of his quiet influence and accurate comfort with certain teams.
player_observations.Charlie: Used the information flow well as assassin, correctly piecing together Merlin from nuanced behavior instead of obvious table talk. Stayed reasonably under the radar, not overreaching for control, which preserved credibility for the final guess.
player_observations.Diana: Played straightforward, trusting, and generally pro-team, which made her look reliably good and a safe inclusion on missions. She didn’t overanalyze voting patterns, which helped evil blend in but also meant she was less likely to catch subtle information leaks from Merlin or coordination from evil.
